a doctor should never speed up a person's death by giving him harmful drugs, even if the patient wants to die. but if a patient wants to be let off medicine or whatever might be keeping him alive, then he/she has every right to do that. if i was 100 years old, i probably wouldnt want to live with a bunch of tubes running up my nose either.

Give me the lethal injection I say.
 
 If I'm diagnosed with some mental disease that's going to leave me a vegetable in a couple of months, I'd rather end it now rather than put myself and family through that.
 
 People have the right to deceide how and when they die, regardless of their situation. Yes it should be legal and if someone I knew asked me to, I'd do the deed for them.

leaving them on life support just to prolong death does more harm than good. The family is often overloaded with this. DNR orders are another point, a person may order this and it has to be observed. 
 
 This is completely different from doctor assisted suicide, which I dont support.

"Well there is a difference between euthanasia and pulling the plug on someone who can't live without a dozen machines."
 
 Pulling 'the plug' on someone IS euthanasia, it's called passive euthanasia. If the doctor pulls it with the patients consent its voluntary passive euthanasia and if not its involuntary passive euthanasia.

Yes
 
 No matter how meticulous you plan your life nothing can prepare you for the cruel and seemingly indiscriminate blow of terminal disease. Personally I don't think we should make it worse than it needs to be. Let people have control over their own lives. If someone wants to die we can't deny them the right. These people applicable are not rejecting the sanctitiy of life. I agree with the popular argument that life should be cherished but I think life is a gift with a heavy price for millions of people around the world and that sometimes the gift runs out leaving nothing more than an evil filled with pain and distress.

To answer the question whether it should be legal, I'd say yes. It is a persons right to choose and making it legal would offer a better alternative to trying to commit suicide on your own.
 
 However, there have to be regulations. Before a person can go through with this, they have to wait at least a month and not waiver in their decision. Their decision has to be made known to their family as well. It shouldn't be something that some depressed drunk can just stumble into the clinic and be dead an hour later.

There are several problems with euthenasia. First, for it to be legal, you would have to make suicide legal. If you think suicide should be legal then think about this. How many people that try to commit suicide and don't succeed go back and do it again? Very few. You hear stories all the time about people trying to commit suicide, not being able to, recovering, and living great, fulfilling lives.
 Second, if you believe in God, you are denying his power and are rejecting the belief that he could perform a miracle for that person.
 Third, to many doctors would have problems giving people medicine that will kill them. Many would see it as helping commit murder.

Here is an article I found very convincing in the debate about the legality of euthanasia.
 
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3142246.stm
 
 I don't consider myself for legalizing euthanasia across the board but in certain situations such as the on detailed in this article I think it should be legal.
